questions.title: What is critical thinking?
questions.description: Critical thinking is when we try to understand a person or situation by asking questions and gathering information, instead of jumping to conclusions based on our own thoughts and opinions.

questions.question: How can we practice critical thinking?

choices.answer: Observing with an open and curious mind
Asking ourselves what information we are missing

questions.title: All of the above!
questions.description: We should observe with an open and curious mind, and ask ourselves what information we might be missing. Then, investigate and ask questions to find out! We want to use facts to understand something...not assumptions!

questions.title: How are assumptions and facts different?
questions.description: When we only use our own thoughts and opinions without knowing if they're true, we are making assumptions. When we ask questions and investigate what is true, we can collect facts for a more accurate understanding.

questions.title: Let's practice!
questions.description: Let's practice deciding whether something is a fact or assumption. Remember, we can collect facts by asking questions and investigating.

questions.question: During lunch, a new student at your school is quietly reading a book. This means that they don't want to play football.

questions.title: This is an assumption!
questions.description: There could be many reasons why the student is reading a book. Perhaps they feel shy or lonely because they don't know anyone.  Try asking if they want to play football with you - maybe you'll both make a new friend!

questions.question: You find a toy on the ground. This means that someone doesn't want it anymore and got rid of it.

questions.title: This is an assumption!
questions.description: Someone could have accidentally dropped their toy on the ground, and they might really want it back. Try asking around to find its owner!

questions.question: You have a new classmate who is from another country. This means they don't speak the same language.

questions.title: This is an assumption!
questions.description: Instead of making an assumption based on someone's appearance or where they are from, get to know them with an open mind. You might be surprised by what you learn and what you share in common!

questions.title: Let's keep practicing!
questions.description: Now, let's practice critical thinking. Remember, we should observe the situation, and ask ourselves what information we might be missing. Then, investigate and ask questions to find out!

questions.question: Imagine that you see another student running in the school hallway. Why are they running?

choices.answer: They really need to go to the bathroom
They are running away from someone
I don't know...I should ask them

questions.title: Ask them why they are running!
questions.description: In this situation, don't make an assumption about why the other student is running. Instead, collect information by asking them why they are running. It could be an emergency!

questions.question: Imagine you are holding a stack of books, and someone bumps into you and makes them fall. What should you do?

choices.answer: Get mad at them for pushing you
Ask if they're okay and why they bumped into you

questions.title: Ask if they're okay and why they bumped into you!
questions.description: Instead of assuming that they bumped into you on purpose and getting mad at them, you should ask if they're okay and why they bumped into you. It could be an accident!

questions.title: Take a moment to pause and reflect
questions.description: Has someone ever assumed something about you that wasn't true? How did it feel?

questions.title: You are a superstar!
questions.description: Critical thinking can be hard sometimes! But it's important that we try to gather as much information as possible when we are trying to understand a person or situation. That way, we know our conclusion is accurate and based on facts.
